awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG:  PILOT FOR EQUITABLE ELECTRIC MOBILITY: Smart Charging, Smart Parking, and METRO Pass System
awd_abstract_narration:
This S&CC project in southwest Houston establishes a collaborative process with community and commercial technology partners with an overall aim to leverage early Electric Vehicle (EV) adopter regional markets to accelerate equitable development of accessible fast charging infrastructure and EV ownership for low income families. The novelty of the project lies in a community-driven participatory approach that integrates both social and technical dimensions bringing transformational change to EV ownership and electrification of smart public transportation. This will be achieved by a data-driven model that integrates of real-time data for micro-transit, fixed-route transit, and carpooling services can predict and overcome the uncertainties of traffic conditions resulting in uncertain travel times and poor reliability. An engaging process establishes collaborative relationships, identifies adopter indicators, and incentives for equitable EV ownership and transit ridership. The project will result in a templet and framework for implementing smart transit hubs that can be reapplied at other Metropolitan Transit Authority of Harris County (METRO) facilities or to other transit systems as best practices.

Greater access to new electric mobility technologies requires reduction in economic barriers to EV ownership and transportation services. Communities need to proactively plan for transportation technologies to improve the lives of low-income communities while lowering emissions, increasing transit use, and reducing congestion. The intellectual merits include application of emerging data analytics, smart technologies, and machine learning to tackle a national challenge of equitable access to EV ownership and electric mobility. The project builds a model using artificial neural networks to capture complex, non-linear phenomena and parameterize data for real-time decision making. The broader project impacts include developing a digital ecosystem and incentive programs reflecting the national need to stimulate equitable access to EV ownership; regional policy impact demonstrating collaborative partnerships between cities, EV companies, fast charging developers, and ridesharing services; and research that opens up opportunities to use the data for EV impacts on the energy grid and future smart grid research. This project will identify how the deployment of smart technologies can improve the reliability, comfort, and affordability of transit services.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

The PILOT FOR EQUITABLE ELECTRIC MOBILITY: Smart Charging, Smart Parking, and METRO Pass System project utilized the METRO West Bellfort Park and Ride Transit Center in southwest Houston as a pilot. The overall aim was to explore how METRO park and ride sites evolve into intermodal hubs that facilitate EV ownership and bus electrification. Deliverables included: A digital framework for a smart transit hub to establish an overall context of equitable smart, clean, and safe electric mobility; Equity indicators and index for EV ownership and equitable deployment of zero emission METRO buses; A dissemination campaign including a peer review conference paper, planning conference presentations, webinars, and broadcast media.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: The project included community and technology partner workshops and a community survey. Social and technical analysis supported development of indicators for equitable access to smart public transit, EV adoption, and deployment of zero emission public transit.

Smart Transit Templet. The planning grant resulted in a digital templet for incrementally implementing a smart transit hub's components based on expected functions and approach to data management. This templet provides a common framework for planning, defining, and integrating intelligent transportation systems (Figure 1). It serves as a reference for METRO's efforts to evolve into a smart transit service provider. The templet is organized around four services.

  • Smart Charging Infrastructure--strategies for placing charging stations across the park and ride facilities to ensure convenient access for electric vehicle users.
  • Smart Parking Solutions--leveraging real-time data and advanced parking management systems to optimize parking space availability.
  • METRO Pass System-enabling park and ride users to seamlessly transition between various transportation modes (buses, trains, and parking) using a single payment method.
  • Intermodal Connectivity--allowing commuters to switch between EVs, buses, or trains with minimal effort and ensuring a smooth and efficient commuting experience supported by digital displays and user-friendly mobile applications.

Figure 1: Smart Park and Ride System Design

Informing EV Adoption Policy. The City of Houston, METRO, and Evolve Houston are exploring ways to improve access to increase access to EV ownership and use. The Houston Climate Action Plan assumes 70% reduction in transportation greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by 2050. Nearly 90% of transportation GHG emissions are from household vehicles. Therefore, meeting transportation reduction targets will require rapid, equitable adoption of EVs. Equity research included mapping charging desserts and households with barriers to EV adoption. An equity index (Figure 2) was developed organized around three themes:

  • Internal Socio-economic Index--comprised of four indicators including educational attainment, household poverty, renter households, and households with less than two cars.
  • External Index--comprised of three indicators including public charger access, cost of EV purchase as percentage of household income, and impact of Federal tax incentives.
  • Interventions Index­--comprised of the EV affordability gap, access to charging, and alternative access to EV mobility.

These indexes informed intervention policy and related budgets to stimulate EV ownership and charging access. Alternative policy strategies include financial subsidies, public access charging at community facilities, EV charging at apartments, public charging at METRO park and ride sites, and charging access along Federal Charging Highway Corridors.

Figure 2: EV Equity Indicators for Harris County

METRO Bus Route Electrification. Equity indicators were developed to identify priority bus route electrification. This included three overall themes that reflect the environmental burden, transit dependency, and quality of existing METRO services:

  • Air Quality and Health Index--indicators include asthma rates, heart disease rates, ozone levels, and diesel PM levels.
  • Transit Dependent People Index--indicators include transit cost burden, driving age, and access to autos.
  • Access to METRO Services Index--indicators include population density, bus route counts/access, annual average boardings, bus route headways defined in revenue hours, and reduction in GHG per rider mile due to electrification.

These indexes were used to identify priority route electrification (Figure 3), estimate GHG emission reduction by route (Figure 4), and prioritize routes that can accelerate METRO meeting reduction targets in their Climate Action Plan (Figure 5).

Figure 3: Bus Route Electrification Equity Index and Priority Routes

Figure 4: GHG Reduction for Electrification of METRO Bus Routes

Figure 5: Bus Routes with the Greatest GHG Reductions Per Rider Mile

BROADER IMPACTS: This project applied emerging data analytics and smart technologies to tackle a national challenge of equitable access to intermodal transportation hubs, EV ownership and electric mobility. Broader impacts include metrics for improving regional intermodal performance, meeting environmental targets, and establishing equity goals. Decision support provides indicators and indexes informing regional transit agency GHG reduction strategies for commuters driving to transit hubs (Figure 6) GHGemissionreductionsand bus electrification. Most importantly, the pilot demonstrates methods for more broadly addressing equity and environmental considerations for public access charging and bus transit electrification.

Figure 6: Growth Scenarios and GHG and PM2.5 Reductions from EV Adoption by Commuters for West Bellfort METRO Park and Ride
